clinical_study.brief_title: Effect of Community Social Mobilization for the Prevention of HIV in Young South African Women
clinical_study.official_title: Effect of Community Social Mobilization for the Prevention of HIV in Young South African Women

lead_sponsor.agency: University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill

clinical_study.source: University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill

brief_summary.textblock: The overall purpose is to assess whether a community social mobilization (CSM) program focused on young men ages 18-35 years of age changes gender norms in the community. The secondary purpose is to determine if there is a combined effect of CSM and HPTN 068 (Conditional Cash Transfers) on HIV and HSV-2 incidence. The goal of the mobilization activities is to engage young men around the issues of gender norms, intimate partner violence and HIV risk and to encourage them to take action to protect young women and reduce HIV risk in their communities.

primary_outcome.measure: Changes in Gender Equitable Mens Scale (GEMS)

secondary_outcome.measure: The number of unprotected sex acts

secondary_outcome.description: The investigators will measure concurrency by assessing the date of first and last sex and whether a relationship is ongoing among the last 3 partners in the last 12 months.

secondary_outcome.measure: Experience of perpetration of Intimate partner violence (IPV)

arm_group.description: A manualized intervention developed with Sonke Gender Justice Network using a workshop intervention manual and a community mobilization toolkit will be used.
The Control Arm does not receive the Community Mobilization Intervention

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
Quantitative Work
- Men and women ages 18-35 years
- Have lived in study area continuously for the past 12 months
- Able and willing to provide informed consent
Qualitative Work
- Men and women ages 18-99 years
- A community member, CAT member or community mobilizer
- Able and willing to provide informed consent
